Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Improving Molecular-Based Research Skills While Investigating the Biodiversity of Parasites in Raptors to Better Understand Transmission Processes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who needs to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Johnson C. Smith University (JCSU) will conduct research aimed at understanding the biodiversity of parasites in birds of prey. This project will be used to enhance teaching and learning at JCSU and thus, help motivate underrepresented minority students to pursue graduate studies and careers in biological sciences. The research and educational efforts will contribute to the University's goal to increase the number of minority students receiving BS degrees in STEM fields. In addition, this project will help JCSU continue to build its reputation as an urban HBCU capable of producing professionally ready graduates and those that are well-prepared to manage graduate school.

The goal of the proposed study is to examine the biodiversity of encysted protozoans in raptors and to begin to unravel the lifecycles of Sarcocystis species that use raptors as definitive hosts. The specific aims of this project are to: 1) Determine the prevalence of encysted protozoans from the muscles of naturally infected raptors by histological and molecular methods; and 2) Collect intestinal tracts from raptors containing Sarcocystis oocysts & sporocysts and determine the presence of S. calchasi by bioassay in cockatiels, Nymphicus hollandicus. This study has the potential to identify new avian infective and potentially pathogenic species. The findings from this study will improve knowledge of the species of protozoan parasites infecting raptors. This project will be conducted in collaboration with the Carolina Raptor Center and Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This HBCU-UP Research Initiation Award studied the biodiversity of parasites in raptors to improve our understanding of transmission mechanisms and molecular-based research skills. Raptors are apex predators that live in ecologically diverse habitats worldwide and feed on prey at many levels of the food web. Sarcocystis species are obligate 2-host coccidian parasites with complex life cycles that cause disease in mammals and birds. The definitive hosts (DH) produce environmentally-resistant cysts (oocysts/sporocysts) in their feces. When these cysts are ingested by an appropriate intermediate host (IH), the parasites eventually move from the intestines to the skeletal muscle cells of the IH and produce sarcocysts. Sarcocysts are infective for the DH when they are ingested. Raptors can serve as either the DH or IH for various Sarcocystis parasites. This project investigated the disease ecology of Sarcocystis in raptors.

In this project, sarcocysts were observed in the heart or breast muscle from 39 of 204 raptors examined. Morphologically the sarcocysts were similar in each raptor. Differences in sarcocyst wall thickness were noted but no definitive differences in structure were detected. Molecular testing was done on the DNA from the muscles of 118 raptors using ITS based PCR and detected Sarcocystis species DNA in 27 samples. Examination of these 27 PCR positive samples using JNB primers and restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) using DraI and HinfI demonstrated that 9 of the raptors were infected with members of the Sarcocystis falcatula complex. RFLP indicated that S. falcatula was in 4 (cuts with HinfI only) and 3 raptors had S. falcatula Argentina-like strain (cuts with HinfI & DraI), and 2 samples were not definitively identified due to low DNA content. We also found that 33 (64.7%) of 51 raptor intestine samples contained oocysts/sporocysts of Sarcocystis species. Intestines from the 21 of the 33 Sarcocystis infected raptors were processed for in vitro studies using CV-1 cell cultures. We were successful in growing and maintaining Sarcocystis from 5 of 15 infected raptor intestines (2 Cooper?s hawks (CH), 2 red-tailed hawks (RTH), 1 red-shouldered hawk (RSH) in cell culture. Sporocysts from 6 raptors (3 RTH, 1 RSH, 1 CH, 1 barred owl (BO) were successfully transmitted to INF- γ gene knockout (KO) mice and sarcocysts were observed in muscle or schizonts in brain samples.  We did not detect infection in outbred Swiss Webster mice.

Our molecular characterization studies indicated that isolates from a CH, RTH, and a BO are different from known Sarcocystis species present in NCBI GenBank. We identified and named two new Sarcocystis species from a red-tailed hawk (Sarcocystis jamaicensis) and a barred owl (Sarcocystis strixi). We developed an experimental model of Sarcocystis infection using embryonated chicken eggs as an alternative to using live birds for research. We also used a Sarcocystis isolate genetically engineered express a fluorescent-label to observe the course of infection in embryonated eggs. We processed Sarcocystis isolates from 27 raptors for use in the embryonated chicken egg model.

Numerous research products resulted from this project. Five papers were published in peer-reviewed journals and two more manuscripts are still in preparation.  Additional research products were shared as described below: Sequences deposited: Four new sequences were submitted to NCBI GenBank with accession numbers KY348753 (18S rRNA), KY348754 (28S rRNA), KY348755 (ITS-1), and KY348756 (cox1) and designated as originating from Sarcocystis sp. ex Accipiter cooperii. Three new sequences were submitted to NCBI GenBank with accession numbers MF162315 (18S rRNA), MF162316 (28S rRNA), and MF162317 (cox1) and designated as Sarcocystis strixi n. sp. Four new sequences were submitted to NCBI GenBank with accession numbers KY994649 (18S rRNA), KY994650 (28S rRNA), KY994651 (ITS-1) and KY994652 (cox1), and designated as Sarcocystis jamaicensis n. sp. Specimens deposited: Hematoxylin and eosin-stained histologic slides from the IFN-γ gene knockout mouse no.744, Pathology no. D9065-2 (containing sarcocysts in skeletal muscle-USNM #1422354), and Hematoxylin and eosin-stained histologic slides from the IFN-γ gene knockout (KO) mouse no. D8526 (containing sarcocysts in skeletal muscle-USNM# 1445754), D 10007 (containing schizonts in brain, USNM# 1445755), and tissue culture-slide-coverslip Giemsa-stained preparation showing schizonts and merozoites (USNM# 1445756) have been catalogued at the National Parasite collection housed at the Smithsonian Institution, National Museum of Natural History, and Department of Invertebrate Zoology.

Over the course of this project, six biology undergraduates from Johnson C. Smith University (JCSU) were directly involved in the research. The students engaged in research activities at JCSU including: preparing slides for histology, extracting DNA from raptor muscles, acting as peer mentors for new student researchers, and visiting the Carolina Raptor Center. The JCSU students also had the opportunity to visit Virginia Tech during the summer to gain experience at a research intensive institution, engage in professional development, and learn about research careers.
